message.content: This question requires knowledge of Newton's laws of motion. According to Newton's first law of motion, an object in motion will continue moving at a constant speed and direction unless acted upon by an external force. When a force acts on an object in the opposite direction that it is moving, it causes the object's speed to decrease. This is commonly referred to as "braking" in the context of motion. Option (A) is the correct answer because it describes the motion of an object moving forward. Options (B), (C), and (D) describe different directions of motion but are not related to the concept of an object's speed decreasing due to an opposing force.

This question requires understanding of the concept of force and its effect on motion. When a force acts on an object in the opposite direction that the object is moving, it causes the object's speed to decrease. This is known as deceleration or negative acceleration. Option (A) is correct as it refers to the object moving in the forward direction and the force acting against it. Option (B) is incorrect because if the object is moving backward, a force acting in the opposite direction would actually cause its speed to increase. Options (C) and (D) are incorrect because they refer to downward and upward directions, which are not relevant to the opposite direction of an object's motion.

This question requires understanding of the basic principles of motion and forces. When a force acts on an object in the opposite direction that the object is moving, it causes the speed of the object to decrease. This type of motion is commonly referred to as "backward" motion. Option (B) is incorrect because it suggests that the object is already moving backward. Option (C) is incorrect because it suggests a downward motion, which is not related to the force acting in the opposite direction. Option (D) is incorrect because it suggests an upward motion, which is also not related to the force acting in the opposite direction.

This question tests knowledge about the effect of opposing forces on an object's motion. When a force acts on an object in the opposite direction that it is moving, it causes the object's speed to decrease. This is commonly referred to as deceleration or negative acceleration. Option (A) is the correct answer because it represents the opposite direction to the object's motion. Options (B), (C), and (D) do not represent the opposite direction of the object's motion and are therefore incorrect.

This question requires knowledge about the relationship between forces and motion. According to Newton's first law of motion, an object will continue to move at a constant velocity unless acted upon by an external force. If a force is acting in the opposite direction to the object's motion, it will cause the object's speed to decrease. Option (A) is incorrect because the term "frontward" is not a commonly used direction in physics. Option (B) is correct because if the force is acting in the opposite direction to the object's motion, it is moving backward. Options (C) and (D) are incorrect because they refer to vertical directions, which are not relevant to the question.

This question requires knowledge of Newton's laws of motion and the concept of friction. When a force acts on an object in the opposite direction that the object is moving, it creates friction, which opposes the object's motion. As a result, the object's speed decreases. Option (A) is correct because it is the opposite direction of the object's forward motion. Option (B) is incorrect because it is the same direction as the object's backward motion. Options (C) and (D) are incorrect because they describe downward or upward motion, which is not relevant to the question.

This question requires basic knowledge about the effect of forces on motion. When a force acts on an object in the opposite direction that the object is moving, it causes the object's speed to decrease in the direction it was originally moving. Option (A) is correct because "frontward" refers to the forward direction in which the object was initially moving. Option (B) is incorrect because "backward" refers to the opposite direction, which would cause the object's speed to increase. Options (C) and (D) are incorrect because they refer to vertical motions, which are not mentioned in the question.

To answer this question, we need to understand the relationship between force and motion. When a force acts on an object in the opposite direction of its motion, it causes the object's speed to decrease. This is known as deceleration or negative acceleration. In the given options, only option (A) "frontward" indicates a motion in which the object is moving forward, and therefore, a force acting in the opposite direction would cause the object's speed to decrease. Option (B) "backward" indicates a motion in which the object is already moving in the opposite direction, so a force acting in the opposite direction would cause the speed to increase. Options (C) "downward" and (D) "upward" refer to vertical motion and are not relevant to the question.
